title: When The NASDAQ Leads, Stock Market Bulls Worry
text: The FOMC report came out today keeping rates unchanged as the Federal Reserve continues to buy into bonds, thus supporting the market going forward.  Both the S&P 500 (SPY) and the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) closed green on the day with the QQQs breaking new all time highs from it's recent tumble on Wednesday the 9th.

title: U.S. Markets Are Looking Less Interesting: Harrison
text: Little information was given and almost no major changes were announced in today's Fed meeting. For the next leg of the rotation trade, geography could be much different than the prior leg.

title: What To Watch As 2020 Comes To An End
text: I expect more businesses to close in the coming weeks and months, and anticipate that the upcoming US jobs reports will reflect very anemic job growth. If infections in Western developed countries rise enough, that could be very damaging to their economies, and in a worst-case scenario result in a double-dip recession.

title: Rates Going Nowhere In A Hurry: Fed Stands Pat On Rates, Sees Zero Rates Through 2023
text: No rate move by Fed, which remains “strongly committed” to supporting economy. Fed keeps asset purchase program in place, sees moderated pace of economic improvement.

title: Market winners suggest 'nobody cares' fundamentals are rebounding, all-star investor Rich Bernstein says
text: Institutional Investor Hall of Famer Richard Bernstein, who runs Richard Bernstein Advisors, sees unique opportunities in 2021.

title: Market Recap: Wednesday, December 16
text: Stocks were mixed Wednesday as traders considered lawmakers' final efforts to get a stimulus package through before year-end, and digested the Federal Open Market Committee's December monetary policy decision. Stephen Dover, Head of Equities at Franklin Templeton and Greg Staples, DWS Group Head of Fixed Income joined Yahoo Finance Live to break down the details.

text: Investors hoping the U.S. Federal Reserve would make a concerted push into longer-duration bonds at Wednesday's meeting did not get what were waiting for.

title: Former N.Y. Fed President Dudley on FOMC, Economy
text: Dec.16 -- Former New York Federal Reserve President Bill Dudley, who is now a research scholar at the Griswold Center for Economic Policy Studies at Princeton University and a Bloomberg Opinion columnist, discusses monetary policy, the U.S. economy and Treasury yields. At their final meeting of a tumultuous year, policy makers promised to maintain the Fed's massive asset purchase program until they see "substantial further progress" in employment and inflation.

text: "I'm actually thrilled by all the negativity because it means stocks can still go higher," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Bubbles Are Ubiquitous, Bubbles Always Burst
text: Asset valuations, in themselves, cannot tell us when bubbles will burst, but they suggest when we are witnessing them and the depth of liquidation coming on the other side. Today, equities, corporate and many sovereign bonds (and the funds and ETFs that hold them) are more extremely priced than at any time in at least 70 years.

title: Fed Will Move Carefully, Thoughtfully on Climate Change
text: Dec.16 -- Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says the group will move thoughtfully on climate change and he says it's an emerging risk to the economy. Powell spoke in Washington.

title: Markets Close Mixed Following the Fed's Monetary Policy Statement
text: U.S. equity markets bounced back and forth between gains and losses, and ended the day mixed as investors tried to read between the lines of the Federal Reserve's statement on monetary policy and its pledge to continue purchasing government and mortgage bonds.

title: The Fed Just Gave the Stock Market a Green Light for 2021

text: Dec.16 -- Diane Swonk, Grant Thornton chief economist, says Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell offered the least possible guidance when it comes to asset purchases going forward. She speaks on "Bloomberg Markets: The Close.

title: The Dow Fell Because the Fed Can Do Little Now to Boost Stocks
text: A fiscal-stimulus bill looks increasingly likely to pass soon, but the Federal Reserve is also clearly unable to add much more economic and market support than it already has.

text: The Fed kept rates on hold while also extending bond buying. Retail sales fell.

title: Fed Promises to Maintain Massive Asset Purchase Program
text: Dec.16 -- The Federal Reserve strengthened its commitment to support the U.S. economy, promising to maintain its massive asset purchase program until it sees “substantial further progress” in employment and inflation. Chair Jerome Powell spoke in Washington.

title: Stock Market Today: Nasdaq, Bitcoin Keep Rewriting the Record Books

title: Powell says stock prices are not necessarily high considering the low level of interest rates
text: Low rates are helping justify an equity surge that has gone on largely unabated since the March pandemic crisis lows, Powell said.

title: We still need fiscal support to avoid bankruptcies and permanent damage to the labor market, says BN
text: Liz Young from BNY Mellon investment management says we still need fiscal support to bridge the rest of the gap in the economic recovery. She joins Mike Santoli to discuss the Federal Reserve Chairman's comments addressing the economic recovery in 2021.

title: Federal Reserve Resists Call For Easier Money; Dow Jones Pares Losses On Fed Chief Powell
text: After initially falling following the Fed meeting, the Dow Jones pared losses after Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell explained the status quo decision on asset purchases. The post Federal Reserve Resists Call For Easier Money; Dow Jones Pares Losses On Fed Chief Powell appeared first on Investor's Business Daily.

title: Fed's Powell Says It Will Take Time to Move Up Inflation
text: Dec.16 -- Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says it will take some time to move up inflation. He spoke in Washington.

title: Nasdaq closes at record high as investors digest Fed action and stimulus talks
text: US stocks closed mixed on Wednesday as investors digested the Federal Reserve's December update and stimulus progress. While the Nasdaq composite index finished at a record and the S&P 500 ended up just shy of all-time highs, the Dow Jones industrial average slid. The Federal Open Market Committee decided to hold rates near zero and maintain the current pace and composition of their asset purchases. Policymakers indicated the $120 billion in monthly purchases will continue until "substantial further progress" is made toward reaching maximum employment and healthy inflation.

title: Nasdaq ends at record, S&P 500 narrowly misses closing high as Fed emphasizes 0% interest rates through 2023
text: U.S. stocks finished at or near records on Wednesday, though the Dow closed nearly flat, as the Federal Reserve did little to indicate a change of the regime of ultralow interest rates amid the pandemic. The Fed said it was optimistic on the current recovery but emphasized that the outlook for the economy will hinge on how the U.S. deals with the worst viral outbreak in more than a century.

title: 'We will see things pick up and we'll get a little more support from the Fed:' Fmr. Fed Reserve Gov
text: Randall Kroszner, The University of Chicago Booth School of Business Deputy Dean and Professor of Economics and Fmr. Governor of the Federal Reserve joins the Yahoo Finance Live panel to discuss what to expect from the last Fed meeting of 2020.

title: We're Richer Than Ever
text: While monetary policy has never been as "easy" as it is today, other important measures of financial and economic well-being are not out of line with what we have seen in my lifetime. Total federal debt owed to the public now slightly exceeds our GDP for the first time since WW II.
